qa_pairs.question: What challenges did Marcella Ortiz face when trying to buy a home in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz faced skepticism from real estate agents who didn't believe they could afford a home, despite having the necessary funds. They eventually found a home in Hunters Point, which was a rough neighborhood but still sold for 1.1 million. They had to borrow money from family to make the purchase.
qa_pairs.source_text: my husband actually got kicked out once my husband they said excuse me sir like this is an open house um we need you to leave I said were here to look at the home we we have we have money like we have enough money to purchase this home you know and um it was like they didnt even believe us so I dont have to you dont have to read the through the lines to say that the the to buy a home its just extremely you have to be like you know Rich you know um anyway so um we finally found a home in Hunters Point right on Third and Revere um it was a rough neighborhood but it still sold for 1.1 and um we got the we got it I called my brother I said I need to hold I need to borrow 10. my mom and my dad they helped us out with another 20 and with the money that we saved we had enough we had enough and so we got it

qa_pairs.question: How does Marcella Ortiz feel about the ability to provide housing for her family?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz feels a great sense of happiness and relief at being able to provide a home for her family, despite the stress and challenges they faced in securing housing.
qa_pairs.source_text: and I was like the happiest day of my life you know um because uh everybody told me that we couldnt you know everybody told me that we werent never gonna be able to do it and so um yeah it was uh thats my story right so now I have two girls and me and my husband we are able to provide them with the roof over their heads and um yeah it was a it was a it was a stressful a very very stressful experience not knowing where were going to live

qa_pairs.question: What does Marcella Ortiz identify as a privilege in the context of housing?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz identifies having parents who can provide financial support as a privilege, acknowledging that many people do not have this support and must navigate housing challenges on their own.
qa_pairs.source_text: thank God that I had my parents a lot of people dont have their parents you know a lot of people dont have um that that um its a its a its a privilege yeah you know a lot of people dont have that privilege and they just they got to get it out on their own and its hard

qa_pairs.question: What are Marcella Ortiz's views on affordable housing programs in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz believes that San Francisco needs to implement better affordable housing programs that are truly accessible to people. She criticizes the current system for not allowing generational wealth building and for having restrictive lending processes that exclude many families.
qa_pairs.source_text: if San Francisco wants to do affordable housing they need to implement a better program thats actually a that that people are actually able to do you know like my brother got a below market rate house when he got it when he was 26 years old and he um got it when it was like the the the program had just started it was like three years old and there was not a lot of it was a relatively easier process to go through and um he was able he was able to do it but um you know um now this is another thing about the below market rate homes in the affordable housing its like another big thing is that once you get into a below market rate home youre owning that home but youre not really youre not really because youre gonna pay youre gonna pay for it youre gonna pay for it and then at the end youre gonna you know you paid off your loan but then you can have your house but what happens when you die they tell you in the me they tell you you learn that when you die the the home can go to your kids only if they make that medium income and that income is going to change to the years so if your children dont make enough or make too much then its going to be taken away from them and they will be pushed out you will not be able to you know build generational wealth for your family you will not be able to give your kids anything

qa_pairs.question: What issues does Marcella Ortiz highlight about the lending process for affordable housing?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz highlights that the lending process for affordable housing is extremely difficult, particularly for people without social security numbers or with ITIN numbers, which excludes a large portion of families from accessing affordable housing.
qa_pairs.source_text: there has to be the lending process The Lending process has to be um gone through and and changed because it was extremely hard to get a new any loan and like I had the same exact problem I couldnt get lenders to give me a loan because people didnt give me um alone with my husbands itin number when I went into market rate housing that I had no problem with that I had no problem with that it was the specific Banks they choose say no not the specific Banks but the program the program its written in the program so or I dont I dont know the exact language so I think that language has to be addressed because if you say that people without socials or people with it numbers like cannot be a part of this process that you take out a humongous portion of families and people who are now unable to have access to affordable housing

qa_pairs.question: What does Marcella Ortiz suggest to improve the affordable housing process?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz suggests that the affordable housing process should be made easier, with more resources for people who struggle with English and for families where parents work multiple jobs.
qa_pairs.source_text: I just think that that whole process has to be changed it has to be there has to be more resources for people who have a harder time with English and and everything thats what thats what I feel you know as a as an electrician as a local San Francisco electrician who builds affordable housing

qa_pairs.question: How does Marcella Ortiz feel about the construction of new housing projects in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz has mixed feelings about new housing projects. While they provide work opportunities, she is concerned that they do not offer enough low-income housing and questions who will actually benefit from these projects.
qa_pairs.source_text: is it its a Bittersweet uh feeling for me because when theres projects when theres cranes in the skies that means that I have work and that that that I wont sit at home right but its its bitter for me because I know that all these buildings are going to go up and theres only going to be uh x amount of housing for low income and whats whos really going to move in right what is what what how is it really going to change the city what what is our city gonna you know look like after this project

qa_pairs.question: What impact has gentrification had on Marcella Ortiz's community?
qa_pairs.answer: Gentrification has led to evictions and displacement in Marcella Ortiz's community, affecting her family and friends. It has also brought about changes in the social dynamics and increased instances of racism.
qa_pairs.source_text: being a San Francisco native um and and watching the city change its been rough it has been rough I mean you know um we we see people getting evicted our families are getting evicted my you know my my grandparents were evicted and shortly passed away after once they had to move all the way to Dixon you know my my best friends mom who lived on 19th and Grill she was evicted you know and um and um so many these stories are just its just the displacement it does something it does something to community because its like it really hurts it hurts people

qa_pairs.question: How does Marcella Ortiz perceive the changes in San Francisco due to the tech industry?
qa_pairs.answer: Marcella Ortiz perceives the tech industry as having increased housing prices and changed the city's demographic, making it less safe due to new residents who frequently call the police.
qa_pairs.source_text: I think that one thing that happened with the housing with I feel like its the tech industry the tech industry industry came jacked up all the prices we have a different type of people coming in the city now and its its not really safe because these are the people that are calling the police for every little thing

qa_pairs.question: What is Marcella Ortiz's experience living in Hunters Point?
qa_pairs.answer: Despite its reputation as a rough neighborhood, Marcella Ortiz finds Hunters Point to be welcoming and community-oriented, with neighbors who know and support each other.
qa_pairs.source_text: I live in Hunters Point and they said that this this part of the city is the hardest roughest part of the city this part of the city youll hear gunshots in the night time you know but I can tell you right now that I know my my next door neighbor I talk to him every day my next door neighbor on the left of me I talk to him every day everybody knows the next sober across the street has mental illness the other next door neighbor right here we know his family everybody talks to each other I dont know why is that why is that they um you know uh theres kids running in the street people are helping up each other people are making sure they can get in and out of the parking lot I I dont I dont know why that is they say its the roughest neighborhood in the street the neighborhood in San Francisco but its been the most welcoming to me and its the last gentrified I feel like in San Francisco
